subject: Technology
title: Superconductors: Electricity Without Resistance
description: One-minute skill: Superconductors: Electricity Without Resistance.

hook.text: Imagine electricity flowing forever with zero loss. No heat, no waste. Superconductors make this physically possible.

buildup.text: In 1911, Heike Kamerlingh Onnes cooled mercury to near absolute zero. Its electrical resistance vanished completely.

discovery.text: In a superconductor, electrons pair up and flow without colliding with atoms. Zero resistance means zero energy loss.

twist.text: Current superconductors only work at extremely cold temperatures, making them impractical for everyday use.

climax.text: A room-temperature superconductor would revolutionize everything: power grids, computers, transportation, and medicine.

punchline.text: Perfect electrical flow exists. We just can't do it above freezing yet.

quiz.question: What happens to electrical resistance in a superconductor?
